anatomical location body part affected: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a underdevelopment condition that affects the entire individual
description: ASD is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impairments in development of language, communication, and reciprocal interaction and the presence of repetitive and ritualistic behaviors.(1) Onset is before the age of 3 years.(2,60) The diagnostic label of ASD now includes several conditions that were previously considered separate disorders: autistic disorder, pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS),  early infantile autism, atypical autism, Kanner’s autism, high-functioning  autism, childhood disintegrative disorder, and Asperger syndrome (AS).(60) According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5 ),all of the aforementioned conditions are referred to and diagnosed as ASD.(60) Diagnostic criteria for ASD per the DSM-5  are as follows:

Criterion A: Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts, as manifested by the following, currently or by history: –Deficits in social-emotional  reciprocity (e.g., failure to initiate social interactions; inappropriate responses to social situations)(60) –Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors used for social interaction (e.g., poor eye contact; lack of facial expression)(60) –Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships (e.g., difficulty making friends; no interest in one’s peers)(60) –For the diagnosis of ASD, these deficits must be pervasive and sustained(60) –In addition to documenting the presence of the above mentioned deficits, the diagnosing clinician (a specially trained developmental physician or psychologist) must also specify current severity level of social communication impairments when diagnosing ASD.(60) Because the severity of behaviors in ASD is known to fluctuate over time, the severity label is used to refer only to current  severity(60)

Criterion B: Restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviors, interests, or activities, as manifested by at least two of the following, currently or by history: –Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech(60) -An example of stereotyped speech is echolalia, described below(60) –Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns of verbal or nonverbal behavior (e.g., rigid thought patterns; wanting the same sequence of activities in each therapy session)(60)  –Highly restricted, fixated interests that are abnormal in intensity or focus (e.g., a strong preoccupation with comic books to the exclusion of all other activities and interests)(60) –Hyper-  or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of the environment (e.g., inability to tolerate loud noises; apparent indifference to pain or temperature)(60) –In addition to documenting the presence of two or more of the above mentioned deficits, the diagnosing clinician must also specify current severity level of restrictive, repetitive behaviors when diagnosing ASD.(60) Because the severity of behaviors in ASD is known to fluctuate over time, the severity label is used to refer only to current  severity(60)

Criterion C: Symptoms must be present in the early-developmental period (but might not fully manifest until social demands exceed limited capacities, or might be masked by learned strategies later in life)(60)
Criterion D: Symptoms cause clinical significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of current functioning(60)

Criterion E: These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability or global developmental delay(60) –Intellectual disability often co-occurs  with ASD; in order for both diagnoses to be applicable, social functioning would be impaired more than would be expected given the individual’s developmental level and cognitive functioning(60)

The diagnosing clinician will also specify the following when diagnosing ASD: –With or without accompanying intellectual impairment(60) –With or without accompanying language impairment(60) –Associated with another neurodevelopmental, mental, or behavioral disorder(60) –With catatonia(60)
Severity levels in ASD(60) –Level 3 – requiring very substantial support –Level 2 – requiring substantial support –Level 1 – requiring supports

presentation signs and symptoms: Communication deficits in individuals with ASD vary greatly and depend on the severity of the disorder and any accompanying cognitive deficits. Communication has been described as "delayed," as well as "deviant," with the primary areas of deficit in language pragmatics and speech prosody

The following are some common communication symptoms: –Reduced responsiveness to others’ communication (e.g., failure to respond to name)(4) –Echolalia (immediate or delayed imitation of what is heard; e.g., the child repeats the tagline from a commercial on television)(4) –Unusual word use (e.g., using made-up  words or attaching idiosyncratic meanings to words)(4) –Difficulty telling narratives (e.g., does not refer appropriately to characters in a story, errors in syntax)(4) –Difficulty with social use of language (i.e., pragmatics) -Limited use of gaze to monitor conversational partner's interest and mental state(4) -Use of socially inappropriate topics(4) -Difficulty modulating conversational turn length(4) -Poor maintenance of others' conversational topic(4) -Poor sharing of topic (e.g., discourse contains too many details or irrelevant details)(4) -Difficulty adjusting social register (e.g., overly pedantic in informal situations)(4) -Difficulty understanding nonliteral language such as jokes, metaphors, or slang(4) -Difficulty adjusting language for context and listener needs; difficulty with perspective taking(4)  -Reduced use of social fillers, such as “um” and “uh,” as compared to neurotypical adolescent peers(90) -Reduced recognition of emotional states in self and in others(95)

The following are other symptoms associated with ASD:(5) –Repetitive movements (e.g., rocking, twirling, hand-flapping) –Self-abusive  behavior (e.g., biting, head-banging) –Preference for playing alone –Difficulty taking another person’s perspective (appears unaware of others’ feelings) –Difficulty handling/adapting to disturbances in routine –Fascination with parts of an object (e.g., spinning wheels of a car) –Unusual sensitivity to light, sound, and touch –Constant physical movement –Persons with ASD often have other conditions that interfere with their health and socialization, such as aggression, inattention, hyperactivity, and mood/anxiety symptoms(6) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Family members or caregivers might be involved in both assessment and treatment. They have a unique perspective and can provide information about the patient that cannot be obtained through formal or informal measures(13)

The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) needs to be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communicative functioning and when developing treatment goals.(13) The communication needs of the person with ASD should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting(13)

When assessing the language and social skills of persons with ASD, it is imperative to use appropriate contexts, content, and procedures. This might include observation of the individual in his or her own environment (e.g., school) during typical or daily activities(14)

For adolescents, assessment and treatment often focus on functional communication skills needed for successful transition from the educational system.(15) The viability of various communication strategies, the type of setting and functional communication needed, and the level of future available support should be considered(15)

causes: In 2010, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported that 1 in 68 children in the United Statesaged 8 years was affected by ASD.(7)The overall prevalence estimates varied among the 11 different sites included in themonitoring network from 5.7 to 21.9 per 1,000 children.(7) When separated according to sex, 1 in 42 boys and 1 in 189 girlswas affected by ASD(7)
The cause of ASD is unknown, but several risk factors have been identified(3) (see below)

De novo genetic mutations appear to account for 10–20%  of cases; however, concordance rate for ASD in monozygotictwins is 70–95%,  so genetic mutations cannot entirely account for the underlying cause of ASD(2,60)
Research has identified chromosomal abnormalities in six major genes. As many as 20–30  additional genes have beenidentified as having contributory roles(2)
pathogenesis: The onset of ASD is before the age of 3 years, and the pathogenesis is largely unknown.(2) Clinical signs of ASD do appearto be correlated to abnormal development of the brain, including overgrowth and neural dysfunction in the prefrontalcortex.(2) ASD is a lifelong condition, but symptoms and symptom severity often change throughout the lifespan. Thedevelopmental trajectory for ASD is not universal.(85)Several studies have indicated that many individuals with ASD showa gradual improvement in symptoms between the ages of 6 and 10 years, with fluctuations in adolescence and adulthood,but an overall increase in adaptive skills and communication as they mature.(8,85)Other studies indicate that psychiatricdisorders (e.g., depression) and maladaptive behaviors worsen in adolescence and adulthood(9)
risk factors asd: Genetic susceptibility(10,11,60)–In a study conducted in Sweden, researchers found the risk of ASD increased with genetic relatedness. Therelative recurrence risk (RRR) was found to be highest for full siblings, with RRR decreasing among maternalhalf-siblings, paternal half-siblings,  and cousins(77)
Environmental factors (e.g., viral infection, fetal exposure to valproate, persistent exposure to heavy metals) might increaserisk(10,60,61)

Advanced maternal age (35+; to a lesser extent than advanced paternal age)(11,65)–In one Finland study, in which researchers obtained data from the Finnish Prenatal Study of Autism and Autism SpectrumDisorders (FIPS-A),  teenage motherhood (age 19 or less) was associated with higher rates of ASD as well(66)

If the screening indicates the possible presence of ASD, a comprehensive diagnostic evaluation should be conducted by a multidisciplinary team (e.g., psychologist, neurologist, psychiatrist, SLP). relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Individuals with ASD might communicate by use of differentoral language, gestures, sign language, vocalizations, body language, or AAC. A communication assessment should be appropriate to the skills of the individual and assess all modes of communication that are usedIf the individual uses speech for communication, and if there are concerns about speech/articulation ability, a standardized test or an informal (nonstandardized) analysis can be used to determine errors that have a high frequency of occurrence, as well as those that are functionally important for the individual. A sound inventory can be completed for those who have severely limited speech. For specific sounds, the number of omissions, substitutions, distortions, and additions can be calculated. Determine if the individual uses any irregular prosody patterns (e.g., abnormal rate or loudness levels), and if these irregularities interfere with social interaction or intelligibility(79) Analyzes articulation patterns based on production of 109 colored picture stimuli(78) Assesses articulation of consonants in initial, medial, and final word positions, including consonant blends, and evaluates connected speech(80) Evaluates all consonants sounds in all word positions, as well as vowels and diphthongs. Also assesses sound errors in connected speechLanguage assessment will include a combination of formal and informal measures (e.g., language samples, observations) to assess syntax, semantics, and pragmatics. Syntax and semantic abilities usually correspond with mental age, and pragmatic ability is usually the most impaired in individuals with ASD. Informal language measures are particularly useful in identifying pragmatic language deficits.(32) Adolescents with concomitant language impairment have difficulty forming and maintaining friendships, maintaining independence, and sustaining some type of employment(33)Videotaped language samples are useful for examining the individual’s pragmatic skills, such as responsiveness to communication, ability to interpret a conversational partner's intent, ability to retell a narrative or past experience, metalinguistic skills, and ability to maintain topic.(32) Language samples can also assess word use/vocabulary, presence of echolalia, use of nonverbal communication, and syntactic elements such as pronoun use. Possible prompts for a conversational sample include "Tell me about your family," "Tell me about school/work," and "Tell me what you do when you're not at school/work." When possible, observe the individual's language in a regular, daily situation such as in the classroomThere are no comprehensive formal language measures that have been standardized for adolescents with ASD. relevant tests and measures.aac assessment: Individuals with ASD might require the use of AAC. AAC can be aided or unaided. Aided AAC requires external equipment, such as picture books/cards, communication boards, or computerized speech-generating  devices. Unaided AAC refers to communication techniques that the person can produce without external resources, such as manual signs, gestures, and facial expressions.(30) Many individuals with ASD use both types, and AAC might be used in addition to oral language. Individuals with very little speech and/or oral language might benefit from a referral for an AAC evaluation. The most appropriate model for this assessment is a team assessment with participation and input from family members.(31) If –What type of AAC does the individual use? –Is he or she comfortable with the AAC being used? –How long has the individual used AAC?  –Does AAC improve communicative efforts both receptively and expressively? –The SLP and communication assessment team should always consider the cultural, linguistic, and economic background of the family during assessment and when making recommendations regarding AAC use(30) –For detailed information on assessment for AAC for individuals with ASD, as well as information on treatment utilizing AAC, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic

In a study conducted in the United States, researchers conducted a secondary data analysis of the National Longitudinal Transition Study-2  longitudinal data set to determine what factors were important in obtaining paid employment for 4,167 individuals with ASD who were leaving high school.(68) Researchers reported the following: –Annual household income and parental education were significantly associated with obtaining paid employment after high school for students with ASD.(68) Annual household income had the largest effect of any factor on the odds of participation in post–high  school employment; hence, researchers recommended that clinicians be aware of family needs and provide additional support and resources to those children with ASD from low-income  families who are transitioning from high school to the job market(68) –With respect to student-related  factors, the absence of intellectual disability, having a high school diploma, the presence of adequate social skills, having received career counseling in high school, and being female were all significantly associated with postsecondary school employment for individuals with ASD who are leaving high school(68)

Researchers found that improvement in overall symptoms and reduction in maladaptive behaviors was associated with higher rates of maternal praise as measured in conversation samples and higher quality mother-child  relationships as measured by the Positive Affect Index(85)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to a behavioral psychologist or behavioral specialist to assist with challenging behaviors. Refer to a nutritionist if food preferences and mealtime aversions interfere with nutritional intake. Refer to an occupational therapist for a sensory processing and ADL assessment.(43) Social services can assist the family in negotiating assistance systems (e.g., medical services, daycare, vocational rehabilitation), as well as finding appropriate employment, if this is a goal for the patient
treatment summary: ABA: ABA is based on the theory of operant conditioning and is designed to eliminate negative behaviors and increase positive ones. Operant conditioning principles include shaping (reinforcing increasingly accurate versions of desired responses), chaining (reinforcing individual responses in a sequence to form a complex behavior), and discrimination training (teaching the individual to perform a behavior when one antecedent is presented and not when another is presented). Therapy is usually provided in a one-to-one discrete trial format, and targets can include a variety of communicative functions, including preverbal communication, requesting desired items, social language (e.g., please, thank you), positive interactions with peers, answering why-questions,  and overall increased communication.(46) The use of ABA requires specific training. For more information, see research and guidelines by Lovaas(47)

Gentle teaching: Gentle teaching incorporates many of the principles of ABA, including extinction, fading, reinforcement, and errorless learning; however, it has been described as emphasizing the nurturing relationship between the therapist and the individual with ASD(48)

Functional communication training (FCT): The method of FCT is to determine the motivation for, or purpose of, a challenging behavior and then teach a more appropriate replacement behavior. This approach is often used with individuals with ASD who exhibit challenging behaviors (e.g., tantrums, aggression, self-injury). Most of the research on FCT is limited to single-subject  studies, but there is preliminary evidence that FCT is effective in eliminating negative behaviors and generalization of new language skills to other people and environments(49)

Environmental modifications: Environmental modifications are intended to provide the individual with increased opportunities to communicate, as well as promote communication development and/or literacy learning. Environmental modifications may include picture schedules, picture prompts, seating next to a peer helper, and elimination of distracting stimuli (auditory and visual)

Classroom-based  interventions –Treatment and Education of Autistic and related Communication-handicapped  Children (TEACCH) -TEACCH is a classroom-based  program that emphasizes structure and consistency in a carefully designed environment. Visual supports, such as charts, clearly labeled physical spaces, and picture schedules, are used to supplement auditory information. The aim is to facilitate the independence of children and adolescents with ASD by providing predictable routines and visual supports -In a meta-analysis  of 13 clinical studies, researchers assessed the clinical effectiveness of TEACCH. Effects of TEACCH on perceptual, motor, cognitive and verbal skills were small. Effects on daily living skills, communication and motor functioning were negligible. The greatest gains were in improving social and maladaptive behaviors. Researchers caution that results should be considered exploratory given the small base of studies(81)

Video modeling –The purpose of video modeling is to teach an individual with ASD a particular communication skill through observational learning. The video format is intended to decrease the anxiety that may be associated with direct therapy –Steps in the video modeling approach(49) -Videotaped images are made of a target behavior or skill -The individual watches the video clips -After viewing the clips, the individual practices the skills with a therapist -The individual then practices the skill in other settings to provide for generalization -The individual observes the videotape again as necessary

Social skills interventions: Social skills interventions include social skills training, the use of social stories, and cognitive behavioral training(50)  –Social skills training(50) -In social skills training, individuals are taught discrete social skills, such as perspective taking, conversational skills, problem solving, emotional awareness, and regulation -Methods used include coaching, modeling, role plays, social scripts, virtual reality (e.g., navigating a virtual playground scene),(51) feedback, and written cueing in individual or group therapy -Authors of a systematic review of group-based  social skills interventions (GSSIs) for adolescents with high-functioning ASD examined effectiveness of a variety of GSSIs in improving social skills of adolescents with ASD. Researchers report that intervention characteristics (e.g. teaching strategies, targeted skills) varied considerably. Results consistently showed high parent and child satisfaction with interventions; however, overall results were generally inconclusive. Authors suggest that future research should more rigorously evaluate methodology(82) -In a study conducted in Canada of adolescents with ASD (N = 46), researchers examined the effectiveness of a 12-week social skills training program on social skills and problem behaviors. Participants were divided into groups of 7–8 that met weekly for 1.5 hours each session.(52) The format of the group sessions included a standard sequence of activities: check-in,  review of the previous week's social skill, introduction of the new skills, role play, snack break, activity (group game such as charades), and closing. Pre- and posttest measures included three parent questionnaires, one measuring social competence, and two measuring aberrant behaviors. Social skills addressed included awareness and expression of feelings, making eye contact, politeness, starting a conversation, listening to others, dining etiquette, and dating. Significant gains were seen on all posttreatment measures and effect sizes ranged from 0.34 to 0.72 -In a study conducted in the United States, including five high school students with intellectual disability and ASD, researchers used a communication book in combination with opportunities to interact with general education peers to promote social skills(53) -The communication books included conversational topics and questions for the students with ASD to use as a reference during conversations with their general education peers(53) -Two of the participants were able to read the questions aloud to conversational partners and then verbally expand on the topics(53) -Two other participants were nonverbal, but used gesture and pointing to have their peers read the questions and initiate conversation(53) -The fifth participant did not read, but instead verbally interacted with communication partners who could read the questions from the communication book(53) -After the intervention, all five participants indicated verbally or nonverbally that they had met their social goals of having more friends(53) -In a study conducted in the United States with 28 participants with ASD aged 10–16years  enrolled in a social skills training program, researchers studied two groups of children: one aged 10–13  years and one group of adolescents aged 13–16  years.(72) In one of the intervention groups of 10–13  year olds, there were two typically developing peers that served as social role models. Intervention involved 22 weekly sessions with the following activities: structured introduction time, a didactic lesson with social topics (e.g., friendships, conversations), an unstructured playground time, an unstructured game playing time (e.g., Uno, Jenga, Tinker Toys), and a structured joke-telling  time. After each session, participants were given a short homework assignment. During the intervention sessions, parents and some siblings attended educational/support groups. At the conclusion of the study, researchers used behavioral coding to document changes resulting from the social skills training program. Researchers reported the following positive findings: responding vocalizations increased and “other” (nondirected) vocalizations decreased; participants spent more time with the peer group and less time interacting with the group leader; and participants engaged more in dyadic interactions with peers by the end of the intervention.(72) One finding that was unexpected was that the number of initiating vocalizations decreased over time; however, researchers reported that this might have been a result of longer/ more frequent conversations among group members, resulting in less of a need to initiate new conversations(72) -In a study conducted in the United States with 45 children and adolescents aged 8–18  years with ASD or disruptive behavior disorder (DBD), participants were divided into an experimental group (n = 24) and control group (n = 21).(73) The children and adolescents in the experimental group participated in 8 weeks of social skills group therapy in an outpatient setting.(73) Each session lasted for 1 hour and included a maximum of eight participants; groups were formed according to age (8–11  and 12–18).(73) The groups were led by a multidisciplinary team including licensed clinical  psychologists, postdoctoral psychology fellows, pre-doctoral  psychology interns, and doctoral students enrolled in an ABA program.(73)Group sessions were based on the SCORE (Social Skills for Cooperative Groups) manual-based curriculum and consisted of an unstructured social time with snacks and games (e.g., cards, board games), and a didactic lesson in which skills were reviewed, taught, and practiced in role-playing  sessions. Students were given homework assignments each week. Researchers assessed social skills of both experimental and control groups before and after the intervention period using the Social Skills Improvement System (SSIS) Rating Scales. At the conclusion of therapy, researchers found that the scores on the Social Skills Scale of the SSIS improved for the experimental group (not significantly), but remained the same for the control group. The scores on the Problem Behavior Scale of the SISS remained the same for both groups(73) -In a study conducted in the United States with six high school students with ASD, researchers used a communication book intervention program to increase social conversational interactions.(74) During the intervention sessions, a peer trainer (a 17-year-old  male with a positive rapport with each of the participants who was receiving special education services because of a learning disability) taught the participants to use a communication book to initiate social interactions.(74) In each communication book, there were 10 to 20 pages that were organized by topics and customized for individual preferences. The length of intervention was different for each participant based on individual needs and speed with which training benchmarks were achieved, but ranged from 7 to 37 sessions.(74) At both the start and the conclusion of the study, researchers performed analysis of conversational interactions with typically developing peers and social validation measures. Prior to having the participants engage in conversation with a peer postintervention, each peer attended a conversational partner orientation session to learn about the use of the communication book. At the conclusion of the study, researchers found that this intervention was effective in increasing the social interactions of the members of the study group with their nondisabled peers.(74) Additionally, participants, peers, and teachers reported high levels of social acceptability of the books in both academic and lunch room settings(74) -In a study conducted in the United States with four adolescents (ages 13–16  years) with ASD and moderate to profound intellectual disability, researchers examined the effect of reciprocal imitation training (RIT) on social behaviors.(75) RIT is a naturalistic behavioral intervention that was developed for young children with autism and teaches children to use imitation to increase appropriate behaviors in social situations. Participants received 10 weeks of intervention in one-on-one sessions. In each session, the teacher used RIT principles (contingent imitation, linguistic mapping, following the student’s lead, physical prompting, and contingent reinforcement) to teach imitation skills. The teacher demonstrated actions for the student to imitate and provided verbal praise once imitation was accurately achieved.(75) At the conclusion of therapy, the researchers documented the following: all students improved in spontaneous object imitation (two of the students demonstrated imitation generalization to novel, functional tasks), improvements were found in 2/4 subjects in joint engagement during treatment sessions, self-stimulatory  behavior was reduced in both participants who exhibited it on baseline measures, and naïve observers rated the students significantly better with respect to social behavior in a 2-minute observation(75) -In a study conducted in the United States with seven high school students (ages 14–16)  with ASD, researchers attempted to increase social interaction by having each participant start or join a club with typically developing peers based on the participant’s own personal interests/preferences.(76) The parameters of social interaction used as outcome measures were the following: the percent of time engaged with typical peers, the frequency of initiations made to typical peers, and social validation measures made by self-report.(76) At the conclusion of the intervention period (which varied for each participant based on the specific club), all participants demonstrated improvement in the above mentioned parameters of social interaction. Additionally, both the participant group and the typically developing peers involved in the study reported that the structured club activities were enjoyable(76) -In a pilot study conducted in the United States, researchers assessed the acceptability and feasibility of an iPad app, SpeechPrompts , for improving prosody in the speech of 40 children (from preschool to high school age) with ASD. The app provides visual feedback for users regarding the prosodic elements of their speech (e.g., stress, volume, intonation). The SLPs involved in the study reported that because of the familiarity of the iPad to the students, the app was motivating and easily incorporated into therapy sessions. Additionally, data from the pilot study indicated that there were improvements in prosodic deficits associated with use of the app. Further research was recommended to determine effectiveness of the app for improving prosodic functioning(89)  –Social stories -Social stories are narratives written by parents, teachers, or clinicians to help individuals with ASD understand certain social situations and to increase social initiations. It is hypothesized that the individual will increase social understanding by repeatedly rereading such narratives, which are often accompanied by photographs or pictures. In this way, the behaviors in specific social situations become familiar and predictable. Research on social stories has indicated more positive results in controlled situations than in natural situations (e.g., school cafeteria), and more research is needed to determine the effectiveness of social stories(54)

Self-operating  auditory prompting systems –Self-operating  auditory prompting systems are prerecorded antecedent cues that increase the probability of a desired outcome.(55) These systems can be either step-by-step  prerecorded instructions intended to guide an individual to complete a task or prerecorded prompts to encourage the individual to stay on task(55) –In a study conducted in the United States that included two 17-year-old  boys with ASD and moderate intellectual disability, a self-operated  auditory prompting system was utilized to increase on-task  behavior in an employment-based education training program(55) -Prior to starting at an actual worksite, the boys were trained to use a self-operated  auditory prompting system in the classroom(55) -Preferred music and inserted self-evaluation prompts on a variable schedule (mean of every 30 seconds) were recorded onto a tape recorder and the boys used a recorder and headphones to listen(55) -Examples of self-evaluation  prompts were: “Are you working?,” “Keep working,” and “Are you done with that area?”(55) -The boys were trained on how to use the on-off button in the classroom and demonstrated mastery of the skill prior to entering the worksites(55) -Based on personal interests and rating scales, both boys were placed at restaurant worksites for the study(55) -At the start of each shift, they were assigned a table to clean by their special education teacher; the task involved donning special gloves and cleaning the table, booth, and chairs, as well as placing a menu on the table; at one restaurant, the boys were also required to place a table setting on the table with the menu(55) -An ABAB design was used in the study and took place over 29 sessions(55) -For the initial baseline (sessions 1–8),  the students were given instructions on their tasks, and restaurant staff and/or teachers were able to prompt as necessary to remain on task(55) -For the first intervention (sessions 9–14),  the students were given a standard self-operated prompting systems (the same recordings for both boys). and restaurant staff and/or teachers were able to prompt as necessary to remain on task(55) -The second baseline (sessions 15–22)  involved continuing their work without their prompting systems with restaurant staff and/or teachers able to prompt as necessary to remain on task(55) -Finally, for the second intervention (sessions 23–29),  the prompting systems were reinitiated, but this time they were individualized for each participant based on an analysis of the prompts that seemed to be most helpful for each boy, and restaurant staff and/or teachers were able to prompt as necessary to remain on task(55) -In the initial baseline, the first subject exhibited on-task  behavior less than 45% (mean of 29%) of the time, requiring prompts from support staff 13–38%  of the time(55) -Under the first intervention condition, on-task behavior increased to a range of 70–91%  (mean of 81%) and support staff prompting dropped to 2%(55) -With the second baseline (removal of the auditory prompting system), on-task  behavior dropped to 61–87%  (mean of 70%) with support staff prompting at up to 22%(55) -Finally, with the second intervention condition, on-task  behavior ranged from 75–100% (mean of 90%) with prompts from support staff dropping to 0%(55) -In the initial baseline, the second subject exhibited on-task  behavior 32–50%  (mean of 42%) of the time, requiring prompts from support staff a mean of 65% of the time(55) -Under the first intervention condition, on-task behavior increased to a mean of 69% and support staff prompting dropped to 30%(55)  -With the second baseline (removal of the auditory prompting system), on-task  behavior dropped to a mean of 51% with support staff prompting required up to 22% of the time(55) -Finally, with the second intervention condition, on-task  behavior ranged from 25–81% (mean of 59%) with prompts from support staff dropping to range of 1–17%  with a mean of 10%(55) -Although the self-operated  auditory prompting system was more effective for the first subject, both subjects benefited from tailored self-operated auditory prompting systems in terms of increased on-task  behaviors and decreased outside staff prompting needed(55)

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) –The focus of CBT when used for adolescents with ASD is to teach the individual to develop social thinking and social expectations. Four steps for developing social thinking are presented here in a simplified format.(17) An example of CBT to enhance social skills can be found in Winner (2003):(56) -Step 1: The individual with ASD is taught to think about what he or she knows about the person with whom he or she would like to communicate. The individual is also taught to infer things about the person: what school they go to, where they live, what people they know -Step 2: The individual with ASD is taught to establish a physical presence by approaching in a relaxed and natural manner -Step 3: The individual is taught to "think with your eyes" to try to determine what his or her communicative partner is thinking or feeling -Step 4: The individual is taught to use language to relate to others (e.g., to look and seem interested in the topic of conversation) -CBT has also shown to be effective in reducing anxiety in individuals with ASD.(84) Researchers in the United States examined the effectiveness of one CBT program on 24 adolescents (ages 13–18)  with high-functioning  ASD. Significant reductions in anxiety were noted following the 14-session  program. Low rates of anxiety were maintained at a 3 month follow-up(83)

Interventions to improve executive functioning: Picture schedules, video prompting, and personal digital assistants (PDAs) have been used to assist adolescents with ASD in initiating and completing tasks –In a single-group  study (N = 22) conducted in the United States, researchers investigated the effectiveness of training high school adolescents with ASD to use PDAs in order to help them remember appointments.(18) After four sessions of training, participants used the PDAs for 8 weeks. They received pre- and posttest assessments of occupational performance, and the devices were examined for frequency of use. At the end of 8 weeks, all participants showed improved occupational performance and most participants were able to use the device software as trained. All participants reported that use of the devices increased their independence in performing daily functional activities –Authors of a literature review published in 2015 that included 16 studies reported that visual activity schedules were effective for individuals with ASD in reducing problem behaviors, improving latency from task direction to task completion, and increasing appropriate and independent transitions between activities. Authors noted that their findings substantiated previous research supporting the use of visual activity schedules for individuals with ASD(87)

AAC –Many adolescents with ASD do not develop oral language to meet their daily communication needs and benefit from AAC to increase their language comprehension, as well as from use of AAC for expressive language(38) –Unaided approaches to AAC involve using the individual's body to communicate by means of manual signs, gestures, vocalizations, facial expressions, or body movements(57) –Aided communication approaches include light-technology devices and high-technology  devices. Light-technology  AAC refers to nonelectronic external devices, such as alphabet boards, symbol-based  topic boards, dry erase boards, and programs such as the Picture Exchange Communication System (PECS). High-technology  systems are electronic devices such as speech-generating  devices (SGDs)(58) –Authors of a literature review of studies that used instructional/assistive technology to teach academic skills to students with ASD found only four studies that met the “acceptable” quality criteria for the review. Overall, authors report a low level of evidence for using technology-based  interventions for academic skill training in this population of students. Review authors concluded that technology-based  interventions intended to teach academic skills to students with ASD should be “used with caution”(63)  –For detailed information on treatment of individuals with ASD utilizing AAC, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic .
